title: 115_s992
content: The Act titled "Veteran Overmedication Prevention Act of 2017" mandates an independent review by the Department of Veterans Affairs of certain veteran suicides. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must arrange for a review by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine on the deaths of covered veterans who died by suicide in the five-year period before the Act's enactment. The review will cover the total number of suicides, violent deaths, and accidental deaths among covered veterans during that period. The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine will review the deaths of covered veterans who died by suicide in the five-year period before the Act's enactment. This includes a comprehensive list of prescribed medications and substances found in toxicology reports, along with medical diagnoses leading to medication prescriptions for conditions like post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury. The number of covered veterans concurrently on multiple medications prescribed to treat post-traumatic stress disorder, traumatic brain injury, military sexual trauma, and other anxiety and depressive disorders is being monitored. Additionally, the number of covered veterans not taking any prescribed medication for these conditions is also being tracked. The Department monitors the number of covered veterans on multiple medications for various mental health conditions. They also track the use of non-medication first-line treatments and the subsequent prescribing of medication if the initial treatment is ineffective. The Department continually updates clinical practice guidelines for prescribing medication. The Department evaluates the use of pain scores as the 5th Vital Sign Toolkit and its impact on veterans on multiple medications. Efforts are made to maintain appropriate staffing levels for mental health professionals. The Department is evaluating strategies to increase the representation of mental health counselors and therapists in the behavioral health workforce, including eligibility criteria and participation assessment. The Department is assessing the development of hiring guidelines for mental health professionals and determining staffing ratios. The Secretary is working with the Office of Personnel Management to create an occupational series for mental health. The Department is working on creating an occupational series for mental health counselors and marriage and family therapists. Additionally, they are assessing the percentage of covered veterans with combat experience or trauma related to combat experience. The Department is analyzing high prescription and suicide rates at medical facilities for veterans. They are also examining programs that collaborate with State Medicaid agencies and Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, including sharing prescription and behavioral health data for veterans. Additionally, they are looking into whether Department staff check State prescription drug monitoring programs before prescribing medications to veterans. The Department is analyzing prescription practices for veterans to prevent overprescribing. They are also studying collaborations with medical examiners' offices to determine veteran mortality and best practices for sharing death certificate data. Additionally, they are assessing patterns in veteran death certificate data reported by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will compile data in a way that allows for analysis across all fields to inform clinical practice guidelines. The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine will review and submit a report on veterans' health within 180 days. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will then report the results to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs and make it publicly available. The term "black box warning" refers to a warning on prescription drug labels. The term "covered veteran" refers to a veteran who received care from the Department of Veterans Affairs within five years of their death. "First-line treatment" is a highly recommended intervention in clinical practice guidelines. "State" includes all states, territories, and possessions of the United States.
